properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected over the Highlands today. Total snowfall: up to 20 cm over the Highlands and 5 cm elsewhere. Locations: over the Highlands of Inverness and Victoria Counties. Time span: early this morning to this evening. Remarks: Snow, heavy at times over the Highlands, began early this morning and then tapered to flurries. Total snowfall accumulations near 20 cm are expected over the highest terrain, with significantly lesser amounts over lower elevations and along the coast. Reduced visibility is likely over exposed areas at times today and this evening with strong northerly winds gusting up to 60 km/h this evening. Onshore flurries will persist tomorrow, but with no significant amounts nor strong winds. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-21T04:59:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-20T21:25:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3746590378.2019
Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme cold conditions are expected this evening. The coldest wind chill values will be near minus 55. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A stream of moisture from the Pacific continues to push in to southwestern Alberta, and precipitation continues to fall in the Rockies. In northern regions, near Kananaskis, precipitation is generally falling as snow. However, in southern regions near, Crowsnest Pass, precipitation is falling as wet snow or rain. This precipitation is expected to continue through Saturday before the system moves eastward. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-21T14:41:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-20T22:42:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0799577338.2019

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions will continue in Gjoa Haven until this evening. Blizzard conditions have also developed in Kugaaruk and will persist until tonight. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-21T01:59:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-20T20:29:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1315759562.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Snowfall is expected to continue in Banff National Park through Saturday. Total amounts will vary through the region, but generally amounts will range from 20 to 30 centimetres by Saturday evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-21T14:31:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-20T22:32:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1562713308.2019
Area: Clearwater Co. near Siffleur Wilderness Area, Banff Nat. Park near Saskatchewan River Crossing, Banff Nat. Park near Lake Louise, Banff Nat. Park near Banff
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts approaching 50 cm is possible by Saturday night. Another push of moisture is expected on Saturday with 10 to 20 cm possible. This would bring total two day accumulations up to 45 cm by Saturday night. The heaviest snow is expected to fall south of Saskatchewan River Crossing. Somewhat lesser amounts totalling 30 cm are possible from Saskatchewan River Crossing north to the Columbia Icefield area. North of the Columbia Icefield area minimal snowfall accumulations are expected through Saturday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-21T14:33:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-20T22:34:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4000344052.2019
Area: Highway 93 South - Lake Louise to Saskatchewan River Crossing, Highway 93 North - Jasper to Saskatchewan River Crossing

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A multi-day episode of very cold wind chills continues. The coldest wind chill values will be between minus 50 and minus 55. Extreme cold conditions are expected to persist through the weekend. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, continues. A strong Pacific frontal system continues to inundate the Fraser Valley with heavy rain. Additional rainfall amounts of 30 to 40 mm are expected before the rain eases this evening. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-21T09:04:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-20T19:02:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2996740791.2019

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The coldest wind chill values will be near minus 50. A strong arctic ridge of high pressure across northern Yukon will give temperatures near minus 41 tonight through the weekend. A gentle breeze at times will result in wind chill values reaching minus 50. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-21T16:01:56-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. Snow to continue tonight. A frontal system has stalled over southern BC. A steady stream of moisture making its way into the BC Interior has brought heavy snow to the Similkameen today. As of 3pm PST, 18 cm of snow has been reported at the Princeton Airport thus far today. An additional 5 to 10 cm is expected tonight. Snow should ease to flurries after midnight and continue much of Saturday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-21T16:00:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-21T00:01:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3345035513.2019
Area: Similkameen
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. A strong Pacific frontal system continues to hammer the Similkameen region with heavy snow. Snow will continue today and tonight with additional amounts of 15 to 25 cm by Saturday morning. There is also the risk of freezing rain early this morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-21T04:55:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-20T12:56:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3562580540.2019
Area: Similkameen
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 5 to 10 cm is expected. Milder air has settled in over southern Kootenay and many locales continue to report rain or a mix of wet snow and rain. Northern portions of Arrow Slocan, including Shelter and Galena Bays will continue to see wet snow tonight and tomorrow morning with an additional 5 to 10 cm possible tonight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-21T14:49:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-20T22:50:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1776725500.2019
Area: Arrow Lakes - Slocan Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Heavy rain for the eastern portions of the Elk Valley. A frontal system is currently stalled over southern BC. With a steady stream of moisture and mild temperatures, heavy rain is expected to continue over parts of the Elk Valley through Saturday. Close to 30 mm of rain has been reported near Morrissey over the previous 10 hours. Areas near Fernie and Morissey can expect total rainfall amounts ranging from 40 to 60 mm by Saturday morning. Rain will likely continue through Saturday with additional rainfall amounts of 30 to 50 mm possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-21T14:58:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-20T22:59:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3990768858.2019
Area: Elk Valley
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A frontal system has stalled over southern BC. A steady feed of moisture, streaming into the southern Interior has brought copious amounts of snow to many highway passes. Numerous highway closures are in effect, consider alternate travel plans until conditions improve. Heavy snow will continue tonight and much of the day on Saturday. Additional snowfall amounts of 20 to 50 cm are possible by Saturday afternoon. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-21T15:59:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-21T00:00:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0302224852.2019
Area: Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass, Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass, Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt, Okanagan Connector - Merritt to Kelowna, Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. Milder air has settled over southern portions of the Kootenay, and many locations are reporting rain or a mix of rain and snow. Northern most communities, including Radium Hot Springs and Edgewater, remain at or slightly below freezing and will continue to receive snow tonight and at least into Saturday morning. An additional 10 cm of snow is possible by morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
